Most of Bangladesh is plain land.
There are some hills in some parts of the north-west and south-east regions of Bangladesh.
There are some hills in the south-east and north-west regions of the country.
Most of the hills of Bangladesh are located in the south-eastern region.
These hills were formed in the tertiary age.
They are very high.
The name of the highest peak of Bangladesh is Tajindong.
This peak is 1231 metres high.
The name of the second highest peak of the country is Keokradong.
It is 1230 metres high.
Both hills are situated in Bandarban.
The main rivers of this area are the Karnafuli, the Matamuhuri and the Sangu.
There is a forest in this hilly region.
The hills of the north-eastern region are located in Sylhet, Moulavibazar, Habiganj and Sherpur.
These hills are not very high, They are called hillocks.
Most of the tea gardens of Bangladesh are located in these hilly areas.
Some areas of Bangladesh were formed many years ago.
These areas are a little high.
These plain high lands are formed of old alluvial soil.
The high plain lands of Dinajpur, Rangpur, Bogra and Rajshahi are known as Barendrabhumi.
There is also this sort of high land in Gazipur, Mymensingh and Tangail.
There is a forest of Shal trees in this area.
There a small low hill named Lalmai in the south of Comilla town.
Most areas in our country are plain land.
This plain land slopes gradually from north to south.
There are many rivers flowing through the plain land.
The rivers flow downwards.
Some rivers are very big.
They include the Padma, the Meghna, the Jamuna and the Brahmaputra.
These rivers have many tributaries and branch rivers.
During the rainy season these rivers are filled to :he brim.
The waters of these rivers often overflow the banks of either side causing floods.
Following the floods, low lands have a deposit of alluvial soil.
This is how the rivers carrying alluvial soil have formed a vast plain land.
The soil has become fertile.
Most people in the country live on this plain land.
In south-west of the country lies the Sundarbans.
Bangladesh is situated in the monsoon climate area.
The monsoon flows over the country.
Due to the impact of the monsoon there is plenty of rainfall in the country.
The weather is not very hot.
Neither do we feel much cold.
The climate of Bangladesh is divided into seasons according to the temperature and rainfall.
These seasons are: Summer, Rain and Winter.
In Bangladesh, the summer season is from March to May.
During this time it gets very hot The temperature rises up to24- degrees Celsius.
Sometimes the temperature rises over it.
April is the hottest month in our country.
Storm and rain occur then.
This storm and rain is called Kalbaishakhi The storm causes a lot of harm.
However, the rainfall benefits the agriculture.
The rainy season begins after the summer.
It lasts from June to October.
It rains a lot during the rainy season.
The temperature goes down a little.
The annual average rainfall in our country is 203 centimetre.
The monsoon carrying humidity from the Bay of Bengal blows over Bangladesh.
It rains more in the eastern .region
than in any other region of Bangladesh.
The temperature goes down after the rainy season.
Winter occurs gradually.
It lasts from November to February.
Some years the weather gets colder than usual in the northern region.
The lowest temperature occurs in January.
The average temperature of this month is about 18 degrees celsius.
January is the coldest month of Bangladesh.
